review.title: Automagically encoding Adverse Drug Reactions in MedDRA
review.abstract: Pharmacovigilance is the field of science devoted to the collection, analysis and prevention of Adverse Drug Reactions (ADRs). Efficient strategies for the extraction of information about ADRs from free text resources are essential to support the work of experts, employed in the crucial task of detecting and classifying unexpected pathologies possibly related to drug assumptions. Narrative ADR descriptions may be collected in several way, e.g. by monitoring social networks or through the so called spontaneous reporting, the main method pharmacovigilance adopts in order to identify ADRs. The encoding of free-text ADR descriptions according to MedDRA standard terminology is central for report analysis. It is a complex work, which has to be manually implemented by the pharmacovigilance experts. The manual encoding is expensive (in terms of time). Moreover, a problem about the accuracy of the encoding may occur, since the number of reports is growing up day by day. In this paper, we propose MagiCoder, an efficient Natural Language Processing algorithm able to automatically derive MedDRA terminologies from free-text ADR descriptions. MagiCoder is part of VigiWork, a web application for online ADR reporting and analysis. From a practical view-point, MagiCoder radically reduces the revision time of ADR reports: the pharmacologist has simply to revise and validate the automatic solution versus the hard task of choosing solutions in the 70k terms of MedDRA. This improvement of the expert work efficiency has a meaningful impact on the quality of data analysis. Moreover, our procedure is general purpose. We developed MagiCoder for the Italian pharmacovigilance language, but preliminarily analyses show that it is robust to language and dictionary changes.

sections.heading: IV. SOFTWARE IMPLEMENTATION AND TESTING
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. The User Interface
sections.text: MagiCoder was implemented as a VigiWork plugin: people in charge of pharmacovigilance can extract the automatic encoding of the narration description and then revise and validate it. Figure 3 shows a screenshot of VigiWork for the part that supports back-end tasks (performed by those responsible for pharmacovigilance revision activities).At the top of the screen, it is possible to observe the five sections that compile a report.The screenshot actually shows the result of a humanMagiCoder interaction: By pressing the button "Autocodifica in MedDRA" (in English "MedDRA autoencoding"), the person in charge of pharmacovigilance receives a MedDRA encoding for the natural language ADR in the "Descrizione" field (in English "Description").Six solutions are suggested as the best MedDRA term candidates: The person in charge can change a term (the macrocoding of the next phase) to a pharmacodicoding option (one or more).

sections.heading: B. Testing
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that this project is a project which is, first and foremost, a project.

sections.heading: C. Examples
sections.text: Table III provides some examples of the behavior of MagiCoder. We propose some free-text ADR descriptions of TestDB and provide both the manual and the automatic encoding in LLT terms. We also provide the English translation of the text in natural language (we actually provide a fairly simple literal translation).

sections.heading: D1– anaphylactic shock (hypotension + cutaneous rash) 1 hour after taking the drug.
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: D2– swelling in vaccination location left from 11/5; temperature less than 39,5 from 11/21; vesicles, blisters around the cheek from 11/10.
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: D3– extended local reaction, local pain, headache, fever for two days.
sections.text: In Table III we use the following notations: t1n and t2n are two identical LLT terms retrieved from both human and automatic encoding; t1 n and t2 n are two semantically equivalent or similar LLT terms retrieved from human or automatic encoding; we use bold terms to designate terms recognized by MagiCoder and not encoded by the reviewer; we use italic terms in D1, D2, D3 to designate text recognized only by MagiCoder. For example, in the description D3 "cefalea" (in English, "headache") was codified both by the human reviewer and by MagiCoder; in the description D2 ADR "febbre" (in English, "fever") was codified with the term itself by the algorithm, while the reviewer codified it with his synonym "English."

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: In this paper, we propose MagiCoder, a simple and efficient NLP software that provides concrete support for the pharmacovigilance task in the revision of ADR reports. MagiCoder takes a narrative description of a suspected ADR and produces as a result a list of terms that cover the medical meaning of the free text description. Wepressed and implements the first version of the algorithm, and the preliminary results on its performance are encouraging. Let's sketch some current and future work here. First, we want to prove that MagiCoder will make changes to the language (and the dictionary), and the way in which the algorithm was developed can be found to be a valid tool for the narration description.

metadata.abstractText: Pharmacovigilance is the field of science devoted to the collection, analysis, and prevention of Adverse Drug Reactions (ADRs). Efficient strategies for the extraction of information about ADRs from free text sources are essential to support the important task of detecting and classifying unexpected pathologies, possibly related to (therapy-related) drug use. Narrative ADR descriptions may be collected in different ways, e.g., either by monitoring social networks or through the so called “spontaneous reporting, the main method pharmacovigilance adopts in order to identify ADRs. The encoding of free-text ADR descriptions according to MedDRA standard terminology is central for report analysis. It is a complex work, which has to be manually implemented by the pharmacovigilance experts. The manual encoding is expensive (in terms of time). Moreover, a problem about the accuracy of the encoding may occur, since the number of reports is growing up day by day. In this paper, we propose MagiCoder, an efficient Natural Language Processing algorithm able to automatically derive MedDRA terminologies from freetext ADR descriptions. MagiCoder is part of VigiWork, a web application for online ADR reporting and analysis. From a practical point of view, MagiCoder reduces the encoding time of ADR reports. Pharmacologists have simply to review and validate the MedDRA terms proposed by MagiCoder, instead of choosing the right terms among the 70K terms of MedDRA. Such improvement in the efficiency of pharmacologists’ work has a relevant impact also on the quality of the following data analysis. Our proposal is based on a general approach, not depending on the considered language. Indeed, we developed MagiCoder for the Italian pharmacovigilance language, but preliminarily analyses show that it is robust to language and dictionary changes.
